text: [Music]
I think finding ways to
um to open up the art form to a broader
audience
without compromising the Integrity of of
the art form
itself um that's one of the things that
I think all artistic directors in the
ballet World struggle with these days is
how how do you pull in that audience I
mean you can't really just do like the
Joffrey Ballet did years ago they made a
a fulllength evening work to the music
of Prince um and they got the audience
in there but in the end was the work
itself really something that was not
only kind of pushing the boundaries of
the audience that was attending the work
but actually pushing the boundaries of
the art form itself um so it's it's
difficult to know how to balance that I
think that's a big challenge the work
has to be resonant and Powerful in its
own
right um
and you can Market ballet in sexy clever
ways to get people to come in but if
it's not if it's not an
emotional response that you get from the
audience that's going to make them want
to come back then it's you know it
doesn't really matter how you package
it I think so I think we are I mean
we're a very young company and we're not
even fully fully formed fully
established yet there aren't 20
morphosis dancers that I have at my
disposal for uh you know for 35 weeks of
the year and that's the
goal but I think so I think we already
from our season last year have a
reputation of being um in some ways a
friendly company a company that you can
come and see and um be offered a
slightly different perspective a
different viewpoint on the art form um
and we do that various ways you know I
try to try to come out in front of the
curtain every night and talk a little
bit about what the audience is about to
see and I'll be doing a little bit more
of that this year um we have we
collaborate with filmmakers to make
little shorts that we show between
ballets which um
uh can
be um a little snapshot of rehearsal um
or a montage of um the dancers preparing
in some way for the roles that they're
going to dance by doing that what what
we hope to offer is a little bit more
insight into what it is that they're
going to see again kind of um linking
that final performance
with breaking down the fourth wall a
little bit I mean it's a somewhat of a
cliche to say but I think instead of it
it being you know them and US somehow
finding a way to link the audience to
the work that they're seeing um and you
know it was great I got I got all sorts
of of um of comments from people
who not everyone can sit in the first
five rows of the theater so if you give
them a short film of the dancers
rehearsing the work that they were about
to see beforehand they they get the
opportunity opportunity to see the the
expression of the dancer the faces so
when they see it somehow they feel maybe
they they know a little bit more about
that person that they're watching and
it's not just like a little tiny glowing
stick figure at the back of a of a vast
stage
